author. Selenomethyl-substituted Schiff base ligand (HL) reacts with Pd(OAc)2, Ni(OAc)2 or CuCl2 resulting in the formation of tetracoordinate metal(II) complexes, with the formula [PdL(OAc)]·CH2Cl2·H2O (1), [PdL2] (2), [NiL2] (3) and [CuL2]·2CHCl3 (4). The deprotonation of the hydroxyl group of the ligand occurs with the addition of triethylamine. For complex 1, the ligand coordinates to the palladium(II) metal as tridentate {O,N,Se} chelate. On the other hand, for complexes 2–4, a bidentate {O,N} coordination mode was observed. All complexes had their structure elucidated by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) and a square planar geometry was observed for palladium(II) (1–2), nickel(II) (3) and copper(II) complexes. Spectroscopic data of 1–4 are in accordance with the structures obtained by SCXRD. In addition, diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) data were employed for energy gap (Eg ) determinations, which ranged from 2.24 to 2.49 eV. Complexes 1–4 were immobilized in the mesoporous-TiO2 matrix to obtain four photocatalysts m-TiO2-n ( n = 1–4). All photocatalysts tested were active for hydrogen generation via water photolysis. The best results were achieved using palladium(II) (1, 2) and copper(II) (4) complexes as co-catalysts. The m-TiO2–1 and TiO2–2 produced 20,895 and 13,271 μmol g-1 of hydrogen gas, after 6 h of irradiation (300 W Hg/Xe lamp) and its activity surpassed that of the standards (m-TiO₂ and Degussa P25) by approximately 67-fold and 42-fold, respectively. For m-TiO2–4 the production was 7819 μmol g-1 of H2 in the same conditions, and it corresponds approximately 25 times more than pure m-TiO2. These results are highly promising and demonstrate the potential of selenomethyl-substituted Schiff base metal complexes as efficient co-catalysts for water photolysis applications. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Palladium(II) complex Schiff Base Titanium dioxide Photocatalyst Hydrogen production Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The generation of green hydrogen through photocatalytic water splitting process, using solar irradiation, has been considered one of the best candidates to solve the energy crisis [1,2]. Hydrogen gas is a non-polluting burning fuel and has been considered a clean energy carrier. Also, H2 is a fundamental reagent used in the hydrogenation of CO2 and N2, to generate hydrocarbons and ammonia, respectively [2,3]. It is well-know that TiO2 is a very promising photocatalyst for hydrogen generation by water splitting through solar irradiation [4,5]. However, this semiconductor absorbs only in the UV region (a small part of the solar spectrum) as a consequence of its wide band gap (Eg = 3.2 eV for anatase) in addition to presenting a high recombination rate of charge carriers [6–9]. Consequently, many efforts were directed in the exploration of techniques to extend the light absorption of TiO2 to the visible region, such as, sensitization by dyes [10,11], metalloporphyrins [12,13], doping of TiO2 with noble metals [14–16], and with metal chalcogenides [17,18]. Although metal complexes have been reported as co-catalysts or sensitizers of titania matrix for hydrogen production [19–21], this field lacks in-depth studies regarding the potential of these molecular compounds in photocatalysis. Metal complexes with wider visible absorption spectra besides Se Lewis base anchoring sites in their structures, may lead to greater photocatalytic performance for H2 production [22]. Therefore, the development of new complexes with application as co-catalysts in photocatalysis deserves special attention. In this way, the growing interest in the coordination chemistry of palladium(II) complexes is fueled by the manifold of their catalytic properties beyond H2 generation [23–27], besides their biological activities [28–31], among others. Furthermore, nickel(II) and copper(II) complexes, especially with organoselenium ligands, have been applied as catalysts in organic reactions [32,33], for antibacterial evaluation [34,35], and in photocatalysis for hydrogen production [36]. Many chelating ligands have been used in the formation of these coordination compounds, where the well-known Schiff base ligands stand out as being considered ‘‘privileged ligands’’, because they can coordinate many different metals with various oxidation states [37]. In this way, they can be used in many catalytic reactions [38]. While complexes with Schiff base ligands are well established, only a limited number of complexes with selenolate-substituted Schiff bases have been structurally characterized up to now [39,40]. Based on the above findings, our work is the first to describe the selenomethyl-substituted Schiff base ligand (E)-2-(((2-(methylselanyl)pyridin-3-yl)imino)methyl)phenol (HL), synthesized by the reaction of salicylaldehyde with 2-(methylselanyl)pyridin-3-amine. In addition, metal(II) complexes with this ligand are reported as [PdL(OAc)]·CH2Cl2·H2O (1), [PdL2] (2), [NiL2] (3) and [CuL2]·2CHCl3 (4). Interestingly, a different ligand coordination mode was observed in the palladium(II) complex (1). The selenomethyl-substituted Schiff base complexes (1–4) were full characterized by crystallographic and spectroscopic methods and were applied as co-catalysts of m-TiO2. All prepared photocatalysts (TiO2-n) ( n = 1–4) were tested for hydrogen production via water photolysis using a 300 W Hg/Xe lamp as the irradiation source. The results show the promising potential of all complexes as co-catalysts of m-TiO2 via water photolysis. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All reagents were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and used as received. The solvents acetonitrile and methanol used in the synthesis of the complexes were dried and freshly distilled before use. 2.2 Physical measurements 2.2.1 Ligand HL and complexes (1–4) Crystallographic data for HL and compounds 1 and 2, were collected at 297(2) K on a Bruker D8 QUEST ECO Photon II CPAD Diffractometer, using graphite monochromator Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data collection was carried out using the Bruker APEX4 package and cell refinement and data reduction were achieved with the program SAINT V8.40B. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELX V 2018/2 and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F2 data with SHELXL-2019/1. Crystallographic analyses of compounds 3 and 4 were solved using SHELXS [41] and the refinement was accomplished using SHELXL [42] with minimization of least squares. The data collection was performed on Bruker CCD SMART APEX II diffractometer, in which a graphite monochromator was used that has a Mo-Kα (0.71073 Å) at 296 K. Data from the unit cell were obtained by collecting three matrices, each with twelve images and the refinement was carried out with anisotropic parameters, using the OLEX2 program [43]. Molecular graphics were generated via DIAMOND software [44]. Selected crystallographic data are summarized in Table S1 and the ellipsoid plots are depicted in Figure S1. Full crystallographic data for compounds have been deposited with the CCDC n° 2424672 (HL), 2417826 (1), 2420207 (2), 2419420 (3) and 2471681 (4). A Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with copper radiation (Kα, λ = 1.54056 Å), equipped with a LynxEye detector was used for powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis. The following conditions were applied: 0.02° increment, counting time of 300 ms per step and collected from 6 to 60° 2θ with θ − θ geometry at room temperature, with divergence slit of 0.2° and receiving slit of 8 mm. NMR data were obtained using the Bruker Avance III HD 600 spectrometer (600, 150 and 114 MHz for 1H, 13C and 77Se, respectively). The tetramethylsilane was used as an internal standard in the CDCl3, and the measurements were performed at room temperature (298 K). Chemical shifts (δ) are expressed in ppm and coupling constant (J) in Hz. FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker FT-IR model Tensor 27 spectrophotometer over the range 4000 – 400 cm-1. Raman spectra were obtained using the spectrometer Bruker SENTERRA. Measurements of the ligand and complexes were performed with spectral window of 50 – 3500 cm-1 and 532 nm laser. The UV–Vis spectra data were obtained using the Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrometer. The measurements were done using CHCl3 as solvent, in a spectral window of 200 – 800 nm. The stability of the complexes was monitored over time, with measurements taken every hour for 6 h. The diffuse reflectance spectra were measured using a Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrometer with an ISR-2600 Plus integrating sphere. A barium sulfate pellet was used as a reference, and a spectral window of 220 – 800 nm was applied. UV–Vis spectra data by diffuse reflectance were used for the evaluation of energy gap Eg . The data were converted to absorbance, using the Kubelka-Munk function [45,46]. For the cyclic voltammetry (CV) analyses it was used a Metrohm Eco Chemie AutoLab PGSTAT128N potentiostat/galvanostat at room temperature and under argon atmosphere in dry DMF solution. Tetrabutylammonium hexafluorophosphate (0.1 M) was used as supporting electrolyte. The CV experiments were carried out using a standard three-component system consisting of a glassy carbon working electrode; a platinum pseudo-reference electrode; and a platinum counter (auxiliary) electrode. The ferrocene (Fc+/Fc redox couple) was used as an internal reference and redox potentials are corrected to the normal hydrogen electrode (NHE) [47]. Elemental analysis (CNH) of compounds was performed on a Perkin Elmer 2400 series II elemental analyzer. 2.2.2 Photocatalysts (m-TiO2-n) ( n = 1–4) For the characterization of the photocatalysts, the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained by a JEOL 55 M6360 microscope, operating at an acceleration voltage of 20 kV. For the chemical composition analysis by energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), a Quantax 75 device (Bruker Nano GmbH) was employed. The textural characterization of m-TiO2 was determined by N2(g) adsorption/desorption analyses, using a Micromeritics Surface Area and Porosity Analyzer ASAP2020N equipment. The samples were previously dried under vacuum at 150–250 °C. BET (Brunauer–Emmett–Teller) method was used to measure the surface area and average pore size and BJH (Barrett–Joyner–Halenda) method was used to measure the average pore volume. A Shimadzu CG – 2014 gas chromatograph composed of a Carboxem 1000 column, length 4.6 m with an internal diameter of 2.10 mm, was used to measure the hydrogen production. 300 W Hg/Xe lamp was employed as a solar simulator with an intensity of approximately 1370 W/m2. 2.3 Synthesis 2.3.1 Synthesis of ligand HL Scheme 1 describes the general route to obtain the selenomethyl-substituted Schiff base ligand (E)-2-(((2-(methylselanyl)pyridin-3-yl)imino)methyl)phenol (HL). 1,2-bis(3-aminopyridin-2-yl)diselane (apySe)2 was used as precursor and synthesized according to the literature [48]. Initially, 1.25 mmol (0.430 g) of (apySe)2 dissolved in 15 mL of anhydrous EtOH reacted with NaBH4 (3.75 mmol, 0.141 g), under argon atmosphere for 1 hour. Then, iodomethane (3 mmol, 0.187 mL) was added. After 2 h, the reaction was quenched (15 mL of water), and the organic phase was extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 15 mL). The organic solvent was removed under vacuum and the obtained product (apySeCH3) was used without further purification. Subsequently, the condensation reaction was conducted using a Dean-Stark apparatus under an argon atmosphere, in which 2.21 mmol (0.413 g) of apySeCH3 reacted with salicylic aldehyde (2.21 mmol, 0.24 mL) in anhydrous toluene (5 mL) under reflux temperature for 12 h. After this time, the solvent was removed under vacuum, and an orange oil was obtained. The product was purified by chromatographic column using hexane/ethyl acetate (9:1) as eluent and a yellow precipitate was obtained. Yield: 79 %. Melting point: 78–80 °C. UV–vis (CHCl3); λmax (nm): 240; 284; 369. 2.3.3 Preparation of m-TiO2 and m-TiO2-n ( n = 1–4) The synthesis of mesoporous TiO₂ was performed through a sol-gel method [49]. To a mixture of H2O/EtOH (9/23 mL), Pluronic® F-127 (0.1 mmol; 1.230 g) was added and stirred for 1 hour. Then, concentrated HCl was slowly added to a solution, until pH value of 3. In the sequence, titanium isopropoxide [Ti( i PrO)4] (20.0 mmol; 6.14 mL) was slowly added to the solution, resulting in the formation of a white suspension, which was heated (50°) and kept under stirring for 24 h. Then, the obtained product was washed with water and calcined at 500 °C for 6 h. m-TiO2 (textural properties): surface area (BET): 34.9 m2g-1; average pore size (BET): 19.25 nm and average pore volume (BJH): 0.167 cm3g-1. The photocatalysts m-TiO2-n ( n = 1–4) were synthesized based on the literature [50]. Initially, 0.0100 g of the complex (1–4) and 2 mL of CHCl3 were added to a SCHLENK tube and kept under magnetic stirring. After the complete dissolution of the corresponding complex, m-TiO₂ (0.200 g) was added, and the system was kept closed, protected from light, and under magnetic stirring for 72 h. After this period, the suspension was vortexed and centrifuged at 5000 rpm for 10 min, separating the solid from the supernatant. The solid was washed several times with CHCl3, to ensure the absence of any non-impregnated complex. The product m-TiO2-n was dried under vacuum. The immobilization yield (wt %) and loading value of the new photocatalysts were determined using UV–Vis absorption spectra data from the washing solutions and the supernatant solutions of the immobilization processes. 2.3.4 Protocol for hydrogen production experiments For the hydrogen evolution tests, it was used 1.80 mL of triethanolamine (TEOA) as sacrificial reagent, 18.2 mL of deionized water, and 10.0 mg of the photocatalyst (m-TiO2-n, n = 1–4). The mixture was briefly sonicated in a water bath and in the sequence transferred to a quartz reactor. After closing the reactor, the system was purged with argon gas, to remove any residual gases. The reactor was exposed to light irradiation (300 W Xe/Hg lamp) during 6 h, and the system was kept under constant agitation. During this time, 300 μL gas aliquots were collected every one hour to monitor hydrogen production. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthetic route for the preparation of complexes 1–4 Scheme 2 summarizes the synthetic routes used for the preparation of complexes 1–4. All complexes were obtained from HL. However, for the palladium(II) complexes the difference in reaction stoichiometry led to the formation of different products. For complex [PdL(OAc)] (1), it was used 1 equiv. of HL and 1 equiv. of Pd(OAc)2, and the product shows the presence of one ligand (L- ) and one acetate anion. On the other hand, for the formation of complex [PdL2] (2), it was used 2 equiv. of HL and 1 equiv. of Pd(OAc)2. For the preparation of [NiL2] (3) and [CuL2] (4) the same stoichiometry was applied (2:1 / L:M). Et3N was used to deprotonate the hydroxyl group in HL. Reactions without a base were also performed, however the yield of the complexes was much lower. The crystalline structure elucidation of HL and complexes 1–4 was performed by SCXRD analysis. In addition, the compounds were characterized by spectroscopic techniques such as, FT-IR, Raman, UV–Vis, and NMR (1H, 13C, 77Se). The purity of the compounds was confirmed through elemental analysis data. 3.2 Characterization of complexes 1–4 3.2.1 X-ray crystallography The molecular structure of HL in the solid state was determined by SCXRD analysis and it is depicted in Figure S1. The ligand has a planar structure, with the three donor atoms {Se,N,O} oriented on the same side. In the palladium(II) complexes, [PdL(OAc)]·CH2Cl2·H2O (1) and [PdL2] (2), the coordination mode of L- is different. For complex 1, a tridentate {O,N,Se} chelate ligand is observed, and the coordination sphere of palladium is completed by an acetate ligand in a monodentate manner, as shown in Fig. 1 a. The value of the geometric parameter τ 4 can be used to assign the geometry of tetracoordinate complexes. A perfect square planar geometry has the τ 4 value equal to zero, while a value of 1.00 represents a perfect tetrahedral geometry. On the other hand, τ 4 value equal to 0.5 indicates a seesaw geometry [51]. Compound 1 has a τ 4 parameter equal to 0.06 indicating a distorted square planar geometry. In contrast, for complex 2, two ligands L - are coordinated to PdII, and a bidentate {N,O} coordination mode was observed. Fig. 1b shows the molecular structure of 2 with a perfect square planar geometry, confirmed by a τ 4 value equal to zero. The ligand L- , in complexes [NiL2] (3) and [NiL2] (4), also exhibited a bidentate {N,O} coordination mode. The molecular structure of 3 and 4 is depicted in Fig. 2 . For these complexes, the calculated τ 4 parameter is also zero, indicating a perfect square planar geometry. Table S2 shows selected bond lengths and angles for HL and 1–4. A very similar N1–Pd1 and O1–Pd1 bond lengths were observed for 1 and 2, with values ​​ranging from 2.001(2) – 2.026(5) Å (N1–Pd1) and 1.980(5) – 2.002(2) Å (O1–Pd1). The Se1–Pd1 bond length of 2.3547(6) Å in 1 is in accordance with the complex [PdCl2(PhSeCH2CH2NMe2)]n·0.5CH2Cl2 reported in literature [Se1–Pd1 = 2.3611(11) Å] [52]. Also, in complex 1, the angles Se1–Pd1–O1 of 176.82(6)° and N1–Pd1–O2 of 174.29(8)° are in accordance with a distorted square planar geometry. In complex 2, for the same labeling atoms, the angles are 180°, corroborating with their square planar geometry. Comparing complexes 3 and 4, the distances for N1–Ni1 [1.907(5) Å] and O1–Ni1 [1.821(4) Å] are slightly lower than N1–Cu1 [2.006(5) Å] and O1–Cu1 [1.918(4) Å]. The two largest angles in 3 (N1–Ni1–N1’ and O1–Ni1–O1’) and 4 (N1–Cu1–N1’ and O1–Cu1–O1’) are 180°. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was also used to analyze HL and complexes 1–4. In general, the PXRD diffractograms are in accordance with the simulated diffractograms generated from SCXRD data (Figure S2). 3.2.2 FT-IR, Raman and NMR spectroscopy Fig. 3 a displays the FT-IR spectra of HL and complexes 1–4, with selected FT-IR data presented in Table 1 . The FT-IR spectra of the complexes 1–4 display characteristic bands corresponding to the ligand L, indicating its coordination with the metal(II) atom. The O–H stretching vibration band for HL appears at 3205 cm-1 and is not observed in the spectra of the complexes, confirming the coordination of deprotonated L- to the metal center [53]. Furthermore, the infrared spectra of the complexes display a stretching vibration band at lower wavenumbers (1610 – 1604 cm⁻¹), which corresponds to the coordinated imine group [54]. Typical ν(C = N)py/(C = C) are observed in the range of 1579 – 1518 cm-1 for HL and complexes. The IR spectrum of 1 displays a characteristic stretching vibration band at 1585 cm-1 corresponding to ν(COO-), confirming the monodentate coordination of the acetate group [55]. The Raman spectra of the free ligand and complexes are represented in Fig. 3b. For complex 1, the unique complex with Se–Pd bond, the (C–Se–C) stretching band shifts to 581 cm-1, while for HL and 2–4, the ν(C–Se–C) appears in 598 cm-1 [56]. In particular, the Raman spectrum for 1 displays a ν(COO-) vibration at 1568 cm-1, corresponding to the acetate group. The (C = N)imine stretching bands for complexes 1–4 shift to 1608–1613 cm-1. HL and palladium(II) complexes 1 and 2 were characterized by 1H NMR spectroscopy (Figure S3). A typical singlet corresponding to the O–H group present in HL is observed in 12.53 ppm, which disappears in the spectra of 1 and 2, confirming the coordination of deprotonated L - to the palladium(II) center. For HL, 1 and 2, the aromatic hydrogens are observed in the region of 8.59 – 5.98 ppm. A singlet with satellite bands in the region of 2.87 – 2.36 ppm, is also observed in the 1H NMR spectra for all compounds, referring to the hydrogens of the methyl group (Se–CH3). This occurs due to the coupling between 1H and 77Se nuclei. Furthermore, for complex 1, a singlet in 2.16 ppm attributed to the hydrogens of the acetate group is also detected. COSY, HSQC, and HMBC NMR experiments, were performed to help with the correct assignment of the hydrogen atoms (Figure S4). In the 13C NMR spectra for HL and 1 (Figure S3), expected signals were observed in the region of aromatic carbons (177.9 – 116.8 ppm), as well as a shift of the signal relative to CH3–Se [5.0 ppm (HL) and 21.5 ppm (1)]. 13C NMR spectrum of 1 also showed a signal at 22.1 ppm corresponding to the methyl group of acetate ligand. 77Se NMR spectra for HL and 1 show signals at 232.1 and 377.8 ppm, respectively. Due to the low solubility of complex 2, 13C and 77Se NMR spectra with good quality could not be obtained. 3.2.3 UV–Vis spectroscopy The UV–Vis absorption spectra of HL and complexes 1–4 were recorded in CHCl3 (Fig. 4 ), enabling the characterization of their electronic transitions. HL shows three prominent absorption bands at 239 and 283 nm, attributed to π-π* transitions, and at 368 nm assigned to n-π* transitions. The spectra of palladium(II) complexes 1 and 2 show three notable absorption bands corresponding to π-π* (254, 243 nm), n-π*(331, 332 nm), and metal-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) (470, 472 nm) transitions. Typical MLCT involves a dπ-π* transition, in which an electron is excited from occupied dπ metal orbital (t2g set) to an unoccupied π* ligand orbital. Coordination compounds with metal atoms in low oxidation states and containing electron accepting ligands like 2,2-bipyridine, 1,10-phenanthroline, CO, and many others, can present MLCT electronic transitions [57–59]. The band at 283 nm (π-π*) of HL disappeared upon coordination in the UV–Vis spectra of 1 and 2. UV–Vis spectra of complexes 3 and 4 exhibit three main bands in the region of 240–284 nm (π-π*) and 369–378 nm (n-π*). The presence of d-d transitions can be visualized in the calculated Kubelka-Munk [46] absorption spectra (Fig. 5 ), especially for complexes 3 and 1 at approximately 630 and 670 nm, respectively, which following literature [60,61]. The stability of complexes 1–4 in CHCl3 solution was evaluated through spectrophotometric measurements every 1 hour, for 6 h (Figure S5). The results suggest that the complexes are stable in solution. Solid state UV–Vis diffuse reflectance using the Kubelka–Munk function [46] was employed to estimate the energy gap values (Eg ) for complexes 1–4 (Figure S6), which ranged from 2.24 to 2.49 eV. 3.2.4 Cyclic voltammetry The electrochemical behavior of the ligand HL and complexes 1–4 was investigated by cyclic voltammetry analysis in a dry DMF solution. The redox potentials are summarized in Table 2 and the voltammograms are shown in Fig. 6 . All compounds were evaluated in the range of –2.00 to +2.00 V (versus NHE). The first irreversible reduction potential for all compounds appears in the range of −0.26 to −0.50 V, which can be assigned to the SeII → Se0 redox couple [62]. The second reduction peak for HL and complexes 1 and 2 was observed in the −0.56 to −0.98 V range and can be attributed to the Se0 → Se-II reduction. On the other hand, for complex 4, the second reduction peak was observed at −1.00 V and can be associated with the CuII → CuI redox couple [63]. For HL and complexes 1, 2 and 4, a third reduction peak was observed in the range of −1.14 to −1.69 V, probably assigned to the imine reduction of the ligand [64]. In the anodic region, for all compounds, the first irreversible oxidation process was observed in the 0.66 to 1.09 V range, which could be attributed to Se0 → SeII oxidation process. In addition, for complexes 1 and 4, a second oxidation process was observed in 1.26 and 0.95 V, respectively, which can be attributed to SeII → SeIV for 1 and CuI → CuII for 4 oxidation processes [62,63]. 3.3 Photocatalytic hydrogen production via water photolysis 3.3.1 Characterization of photocatalysts FT-IR, Raman, PXRD, SEM, and EDS techniques were used to characterize the photocatalysts m-TiO2-n ( n = 1–4). FT-IR spectra (Figure S7) show strong bands at 628, 414 and 233 cm-1 corresponding to the ν(Ti–O) stretching vibration [65,66]. Raman Spectra (Figure S8) reveal characteristic peaks of the m-TiO2 anatase phase [67,68]: ν(Ti−O) = 637 and 516 cm-1, and δ(O−Ti−O) = 143, 195 and 396 cm-1. The powder diffraction patterns for all photocatalysts are depicted in Fig. 7 . It was observed that pure m-TiO2 and all photocatalysts exhibited the main crystallographic planes of the anatase phase in the matrix [69]. The same characteristics were observed for m-TiO2–1 after photocatalytic tests, as shown in Figure S9. The diffractograms of all photocatalysts are very similar to the pure m-TiO2, likely due to the low immobilization yield (wt %) and loading of the photocatalysts. SEM images of the photocatalysts (Figure S10) show particles with irregular sizes and no well-defined shapes. EDS spectra are shown in Figure S11 and report characteristic peaks corresponding to the elements Ti, O, Se, N and M [M = Pd (1, 2), Ni (3) or Cu (4)], which are present in the photocatalysts. Elemental mapping (Figs. 8 and S12) reveals a uniform distribution of the elements on the surface of the photocatalysts. 3.3.2 Photocatalytic hydrogen production Fig. 9 shows the amount of H2 produced using m-TiO2-n, through water photolysis, under 300 W Xe/Hg lamp irradiation for 6 h, using TEOA as a sacrificial reagent. The results were compared to the production of pure m-TiO2 and Degussa P25 (particle size of 21 nm; Sigma-Aldrich) (standard samples). All photocatalysts impregnated with complexes 1–4 exhibited enhanced photocatalytic activity, with palladium complex co-catalysts yielding the highest results (20,895 and 13,271 μmol g-1 for 1 and 2, respectively, after 6-hour irradiation) (Fig. 10 ). These results could be related to the highest wt % (Table 3 ) of palladium complexes co-catalyzing m-TiO2 and consequently highest loading values for the photocatalysts m-TiO2–1 and m-TiO2–2 compared to the others. Additionally, the palladium complexes absorb visible light to a greater extent compared to the nickel and copper ones (Figs. 4 and 5), with a greater solar harvesting ability of m-TiO2–1 even when compared to m-TiO2–2, corroborating with the notable H2(g) production of m-TiO2–1. Nevertheless, impregnation rates are low, the complexes have shown efficient activity as co-catalysts of m-TiO2. The stability of the photocatalyst with higher activity (m-TiO2–1) was investigated over a four-cycle recycling experiment. At the end of each run, the system was opened, and argon was purged to initiate a new run. The results obtained are reported in Fig. 11 (top). A decrease of 41 % in H2 production was observed especially in the fourth run. However, the hydrogen production in the fourth run (5-hour run) remained approximately 30 times higher than that of pure m-TiO₂. Furthermore, a long-term stability test was run over 30 h for m-TiO2–1, reaching about 65,000 μmol g-1 of H2 gas until this extended period (Fig. 11, bottom). This result demonstrates that the use of m-TiO2–1 for a long period of time still provides high catalytic amounts of hydrogen gas, although a plateau feature arises in the final period of the 30-hour test. Table 4 summarizes the catalytic performance for hydrogen production of several photocatalysts based on titania modified with metal complexes. The results exhibit that all synthesized photocatalysts in this work, particularly m-TiO2–1 and m-TiO2–2, demonstrate notable photocatalytic activity for H2 production. It is proposed that especially for palladium(II) complexes (1 and 2) co-catalysts, their wide UV–Vis absorption spectra may result in significantly higher hydrogen production compared to that reported in the literature. 3.3.3 Electron transfer mechanism of m-TiO2–1 Based on the electrochemical data showed in Table 2, a proposal electron transfer mechanism between complex 1 and m-TiO2 is represented in Fig. 12 . The photogenerated electrons (e-) can migrate from CB of m-TiO2 to LUMO of complex 1, where the H + ions are reduced to H2. The holes (h +) from m-TiO2 accumulate in complex 1 and the sacrificial agent, TEOA, acts as hole scavenger being oxidized to TEOA+ [74,75]. Therefore, it can be assumed that the photocatalyst m-TiO2–1 promotes satisfactory charge separation, reducing the recombination of the photo-excited e-/h + pairs, improving the results of hydrogen production from water photolysis. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, HL ligand and four complexes with selenomethyl-substituted Schiff base [PdL(OAc)]·CH2Cl2·H2O (1), [PdL2] (2), [NiL2] (3) and [CuL2]·2CHCl3 (4) were synthesized by the first time and fully characterized by crystallographic and spectroscopic methods. All complexes showed a tetracoordinated metal(II) center, presented a square planar geometry for palladium(II), nickel(II) and copper(II) compounds. Spectroscopy data obtained by FT-IR, Raman, UV–Vis and NMR are in accordance with the molecular structures determined by SCRXD. In addition, the catalytic performance of m-TiO2 impregnated with metal complexes (1–4) was notable, particularly for those with palladium(II) complexes as co-catalysts, producing 20,895 μmol g-1 and 13,271 μmol g-1 of H2, after 6 h of irradiation (approximately 67-fold and 42-fold compared to the pure matrix). These results are consistent with the highest wt % and loading of palladium(II) complexes impregnated in the m-TiO2 matrix, as well as their greater absorption in the visible light range. Furthermore, the photocatalysts containing non-noble metals (NiII and CuII), also exhibited notable photocatalytic performance, producing 1083 μmol g-1 and 7819 μmol g-1 of H2, respectively. These results demonstrate the excellent potential of metal complexes with selenomethyl-substituted Schiff base ligand for application as co-catalysts of titania for H2 production via water photolysis. coredata.dc:description: Selenomethyl-substituted Schiff base ligand (HL) reacts with Pd(OAc)2, Ni(OAc)2 or CuCl2 resulting in the formation of tetracoordinate metal(II) complexes, with the formula [PdL(OAc)]·CH2Cl2·H2O (1), [PdL2] (2), [NiL2] (3) and [CuL2]·2CHCl3 (4). The deprotonation of the hydroxyl group of the ligand occurs with the addition of triethylamine. For complex 1, the ligand coordinates to the palladium(II) metal as tridentate {O,N,Se} chelate. On the other hand, for complexes 2–4, a bidentate {O,N} coordination mode was observed. All complexes had their structure elucidated by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) and a square planar geometry was observed for palladium(II) (1–2), nickel(II) (3) and copper(II) complexes. Spectroscopic data of 1–4 are in accordance with the structures obtained by SCXRD. In addition, diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) data were employed for energy gap (Eg ) determinations, which ranged from 2.24 to 2.49 eV. Complexes 1–4 were immobilized in the mesoporous-TiO2 matrix to obtain four photocatalysts m-TiO2-n ( n = 1–4). All photocatalysts tested were active for hydrogen generation via water photolysis. The best results were achieved using palladium(II) (1, 2) and copper(II) (4) complexes as co-catalysts. The m-TiO2–1 and TiO2–2 produced 20,895 and 13,271 μmol g-1 of hydrogen gas, after 6 h of irradiation (300 W Hg/Xe lamp) and its activity surpassed that of the standards (m-TiO₂ and Degussa P25) by approximately 67-fold and 42-fold, respectively. For m-TiO2–4 the production was 7819 μmol g-1 of H2 in the same conditions, and it corresponds approximately 25 times more than pure m-TiO2. These results are highly promising and demonstrate the potential of selenomethyl-substituted Schiff base metal complexes as efficient co-catalysts for water photolysis applications.
